awd_titl_txt: CC* Compute: COllaborative Next-generation Technology In the Northeast: the UMassUnity Machine (CONTINUUM)
awd_abstract_narration:
COllaborative Next-generation Technology In the Northeast: the UMassUnity Machine (CONTINUUM) extends an existing computational resource, UMass Amherst’s UNITY cluster, with eight novel servers that support cutting-edge IBM POWER, GPGPU and FPGA architectures. This extension enables key computational efforts at UMass Amherst and Dartmouth campuses, and the University of Rhode Island in numerous important science areas, including gravitational wave science, metagenomics, earthquake detection, modeling cancer and others. Based on the science requirements, the existing Unity cluster is extended with eight Power9 nodes, each with dual 2.7 GHz 16-core processors, 256 GB memory, accelerated by dual Nvidia Tesla V100 GPGPUs and a Xilinx Alveo U50 FPGA. Beyond the initial science drivers proposed, the new servers support many more collaborative research teams on the three campuses. Furthermore, CONTINUUM enables scientific development for the entire Open Science Grid (OSG) community, with access to 20% of the compute time.

The new servers also serve as an important tool for training undergraduate and graduate students in the efficient use of cutting-edge HPC systems. In addition, CONTINUUM supports research and education in an EPSCoR state (RI) and a university campus in Massachusetts with 38% students of color. To promote collaborations with researchers in the wider region, CONTINUUM personnel participate in the regional HPC Day conference and collaborate with the Northeast and CAREERS Cyberteams communities.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The goal of the CONTINUUM was to increase the capabilities of a high–performance computing (HPC) cluster that serves researchers from the University of Rhode Island, the University of Massachusetts Dartmouth, and the University of Massachusetts Amherst. This new hardware enables collaborative scientific discoveries in a variety of areas, including gravitational waves from black holes, metagenomics, earthquake detection, and cancer modeling, among others. All science drivers the CONTINUUM project supports are using Artificial Intelligence (AI) for their research and the researchers' request for a system that efficiently supports AI algorithms motivated the design of the new cluster.

The hardware introduced by CONTINUUM is unique in a sense that it introduces IBM’s Power9 processors in combination with NVIDIA graphic processing units (GPU). The Power9 processors and the GPUs are connected via NVLink, a high-performance interface that offers a significantly higher data throughput. Consequently, this system is designed to efficiently accelerate AI applications. Additionally, the design of CONTINUUM was motivated by the goal to design a system that is close to the Department of Energy’s Summit system. This allowed researchers to run their compute jobs on a smaller but (almost) identical system, potentially analyze and optimize the job, and then scale them up to run them on the larger Summit cluster.

After the inception of the CONTINUUM compute cluster, the system was heavily used by domain scientists. Their usage of the cluster led to a series of new discoveries, which were published in venues such as the Journal Universe and the General Relativity and Gravitation Journal.

Since the CONTINUUM cluster became operational it is supporting domain scientists in diverse areas, ranging from gravitational waves research to the classification of high-rise buildings in flood-prone areas. All research areas have the potential to impact society. Some of them more in the short term (e.g., flooding) and some of them most likely more in the long term (gravitational waves) due to their fundamental research characteristics. The cluster is also an important tool for training undergraduate and graduate students in the efficient use of cutting-edge HPC systems. For example, students participating in a scientific computing class offered by faculty from UMass Dartmouth are able to use the cluster for their projects. In addition, it supports research and education in an EPSCoR state (RI) and a university campus in MA with 38% students of color.
